pullRequest.body:
... including Jordan's inequality: `2 / π * x ≤ sin x` for `0 ≤ x ≤ π / 2`

From LeanAPAP


---

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8123389311/job/22203744213)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8123389311/job/22203744360)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8123389311/job/22203744279)

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
Isn't it simpler to deduce it from `sin_lt`?

It is, but I was hoping my proof would make `sin_lt` itself easier to prove This seems to not be the case, since the derivative `1 - cos x` is not everywhere positive (and here we don't have the statement that says that if the derivative of a function is ae positive then the function is strictly monotone).
I'd rather have a lemma name that corresponds more closely to the statement.

I'm not sure symbol-reading is better here. After all, this is the best quadratic lower bound you can get on `cos`, and something like `one_sub_sq_div_two_le_cos` does not really get that message across. Also please note the existing `sin_bound` and `cos_bound`.

>  this is the best quadratic lower bound you can get

I'd argue that `cos_quadratic_lower_bound` is more suited to the theorem that actually states this; the current version just gives *a* lower bound, without proving it is tight.
I'm not sure how such a statement would look like, but certainly I wouldn't call it `cos_quadratic_lower_bound` because there will be more specific symbols to refer to.
`alias`?
What do you mean, Yury?
I guess that Yury means: name the theorem according to the naming convention, and create an alias with the name that you currently use.
Might as well rename the lemma at this point

It is recommended to not use the focusing dot to close the goal after `suffices` (just like for `have`).
```suggestion
  suffices MonotoneOn (fun x ↦ cos x + x ^ 2 / 2) (Ici 0) by
    simpa using this left_mem_Ici hx₀ hx₀
```
Same thing below several times.
nonterminal simp

```suggestion
  exact concaveOn_of_hasDerivWithinAt2_nonpos (convex_Icc ..)
```
Don't use `refine` when closing a goal.
When you start a calc block, can you write down explicitly the starting term instead of just `_`, to help the reader?
It makes the indentation all wrong, but sure

```suggestion
  have hconc : ConcaveOn ℝ (Icc (π / 2) π) (fun x ↦ 1 - 2 / π ^ 2 * x ^ 2 - cos x) := by
    refine concaveOn_of_hasDerivWithinAt2_nonpos (convex_Icc ..)
```
This is not in the style guide. Ignoring.
See #6964, for instance.
I maintain. If it hasn't made it to the style guide, it's that it hasn't been discussed enough and agreed upon.
#10534 indicates that it the `·` style is not used anywhere in mathlib (and will make this a syntax error in this file if merged)

```suggestion
  have hmono : MonotoneOn (fun x ↦ 1 - 2 / π ^ 2 * x ^ 2 - cos x) (Icc 0 (π / 2)) := by
    refine monotoneOn_of_hasDerivWithinAt_nonneg (convex_Icc ..) (Continuous.continuousOn $
```

```suggestion
lemma two_div_pi_mul_le_sin (hx₀ : 0 ≤ x) (hx : x ≤ π / 2) : 2 / π * x ≤ sin x := by
```
Can you add `x ≤ sin x` for `x ≤ 0` too? Or is the claim that no one ever cares?
Pretty sure no one cares but they are easy enough to add.

```suggestion
lemma lt_sin (hx : x < 0) : x < sin x := by simpa using sin_lt <| neg_pos.2 hx
lemma le_sin (hx : x ≤ 0) : x ≤ sin x := by simpa using sin_le <| neg_nonneg.2 hx
```
This one is presumably also true with some restatement for negative `x`

nit:
```suggestion
lemma sin_le_two_div_pi_mul (hx : -(π / 2) ≤ x) (hx₀ : x ≤ 0) : sin x ≤ 2 / π * x := by
```
Thanks, I was confused by this too.
What does the `..` syntax do?
It fills in the correct number of `_`
If you wanted you could get continuity from your derivative without applying a tactic, but not necessary.
Good observation. I will keep it like that for now because `fun_prop` is supposed to make all of this automatic anyway
Is it standard to have the _ in front of the first = too?
It is standard (and I prefer it that way) but Sébastien complained the other way around here: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10525#discussion_r1489259915
To clarify, I was suggesting leaving the initial expression and just adding _ to the second calc line.
Can you write out explicitly what you mean?

```lean
calc expr
  _ < … := by …
  _ > … := by …
```

But since that style thread isn’t resolved (and some people disagree with this) I’d say you have lots of flexibility. :)

Yeah okay that's what I thought. Your syntax is (currently) invalid because it's equivalent to
```
calc
  expr _ < … := by …
  _ > … := by …
```
but `expr` isn't a function.
That’s weird, because I use it a lot: https://github.com/girving/ray/blob/48d737369e856f925aa050a317d10ae95726804a/Ray/Misc/Bounds.lean#L142
Uh, I am most surprised. I didn't know that was valid syntax

Could we get Jordan's inequality for `cos` as well?

```lean
lemma one_sub_two_div_pi_mul_abs_le_cos (h : |x| ≤ π / 2) : 1 - 2 / π * |x| ≤ cos x
```

```suggestion
  suffices ConcaveOn ℝ (Icc 0 (π / 2)) (fun x ↦ sin x - 2 / π * x) by
    refine (le_min ?_ ?_).trans $ this.min_le_of_mem_Icc ⟨hx₀, hx⟩ <;> field_simp
```
